name: 3-methylquinoline n-oxide
Reason: 3-methylquinoline n-oxide has a melting point that can be predicted by comparing it to the base unit of benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The methyl group increases the molecular weight and size, which generally raises the melting point. The nitro group introduces a strong dipole moment, which can increase the melting point by approximately +50°C. The quinoline ring itself also contributes to the melting point due to its planarity and rigidity, estimated at around +20°C. The n-oxide group can also contribute to the melting point due to increased molecular weight and potential hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +10°C.
